title: Psalms Chapter 118 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 118 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 118 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 118.

questions.question: According to Psalms 118:1, why should we give thanks unto the LORD?
options: Because he is good and his mercy endureth forever
Because he created the heavens and the earth
Because he is mighty in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Because he is good and his mercy endureth forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:1 states that we should give thanks unto the LORD because he is good and his mercy endureth forever.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 118:3 say should proclaim that God's mercy endureth forever?
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Aaron
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:3 specifically says the house of Aaron should say that God's mercy endureth forever.

questions.question: What does the psalmist declare about the LORD in times of distress in Psalms 118:5?
options: The LORD answered me and set me in a large place
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD answered me and set me in a large place
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:5 states that when the psalmist called upon the LORD in distress, the LORD answered and set him in a large place.

questions.question: According to Psalms 118:6, what is the psalmist's attitude because the LORD is on his side?
questions.correctAnswer: He will not fear
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:6 says the LORD is on the psalmist's side, so he will not fear what man can do to him.

questions.question: What does Psalms 118:8 say is better than putting confidence in man?
questions.correctAnswer: To trust in the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:8 states it is better to trust in the LORD than to put confidence in man.

questions.question: Who surrounded the psalmist as described in Psalms 118:10?
questions.correctAnswer: All nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:10 says that all nations compassed the psalmist about.

questions.question: In Psalms 118:12, the enemies compassed the psalmist about like what?
questions.correctAnswer: Bees
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:12 compares the enemies surrounding the psalmist to bees.

questions.question: What is the LORD described as in Psalms 118:14?
options: My strength and song, and my salvation
questions.correctAnswer: My strength and song, and my salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:14 describes the LORD as the psalmist's strength, song, and salvation.

questions.question: What does Psalms 118:17 say the psalmist will do instead of dying?
options: Live and declare the works of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Live and declare the works of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:17 states the psalmist shall not die but live and declare the works of the LORD.

questions.question: According to Psalms 118:22, what has become the head stone of the corner?
options: The stone which the builders refused
questions.correctAnswer: The stone which the builders refused
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:22 says the stone which the builders refused has become the head stone of the corner.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 118:6 declares that the psalmist will fear man because he is alone.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:6 says the LORD is on the psalmist's side, so he will not fear what man can do.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 118:24 says that the day the LORD has made should be a day of rejoicing and gladness.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:24 encourages rejoicing and being glad in the day which the LORD hath made.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 118:13 says the LORD allowed the psalmist to fall without help.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:13 states the LORD helped the psalmist even though he was thrust sore at to fall.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 118:19: 'Open to me the gates of __________:'
questions.correctAnswer: righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:19 says, 'Open to me the gates of righteousness.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 118:26, who is blessed?
options: He that cometh in the name of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He that cometh in the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:26 blesses he that cometh in the name of the LORD.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 118 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 118 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 118, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in adversity?
options: Trust in the LORD rather than in man or princes
Rely on your own strength to overcome troubles
Avoid prayer and wait for the situation to improve
Seek only human help and ignore God’s guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD rather than in man or princes
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:8-9 emphasizes that it is better to trust in the LORD than to put confidence in man or princes. This teaches us to rely on God's strength and faithfulness in difficult times rather than human solutions.

questions.question: How does Psalms 118 teach about God's enduring mercy and its importance for daily thanksgiving?
options: God’s mercy endures forever and calls for continual thanksgiving
God’s mercy is temporary and should be earned
Thanksgiving is only necessary during special occasions
Mercy is only for certain groups, not all believers
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy endures forever and calls for continual thanksgiving
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 and 29 repeatedly declare that God's mercy endures forever and call on Israel, Aaron’s house, and those who fear the LORD to give thanks continually, highlighting the importance of daily gratitude.

questions.question: A believer feels surrounded by enemies and overwhelmed. Based on Psalms 118, what encouragement can you share about God’s protection?
options: The LORD is on my side and will destroy my enemies
I must fight my enemies alone without God’s help
Enemies will always succeed against the righteous
Ignore the enemies and hope they go away
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is on my side and will destroy my enemies
questions.explanation: Verses 6, 10-12 teach that the LORD is on the believer’s side, enabling them not to fear and assuring them that God will destroy enemies who surround them.

questions.question: How does Psalms 118 instruct us to respond when God delivers us from distress?
options: Praise and thank God for salvation
Forget the deliverance and move on silently
Boast in our own strength and wisdom
Seek rewards from others for our deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: Praise and thank God for salvation
questions.explanation: Verses 5, 14, and 21 indicate that when God answers in distress and becomes our salvation, our proper response is to praise and thank Him, recognizing His strength and help.

questions.question: What does Psalms 118 teach about humility and contentment in the face of trials?
options: The LORD chastens but does not give over to death
Trials mean God has abandoned us
We should despair and lose hope during chastening
Ignore God’s discipline and do as we please
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD chastens but does not give over to death
questions.explanation: Verse 18 teaches that although the LORD chastens the believer, He does not abandon them to death, encouraging humility and trust in God’s loving discipline.

questions.question: A believer wants to live a life that witnesses to God's works. What encouragement does Psalms 118 provide about perseverance and testimony?
options: I shall live and declare the works of the LORD
It is better to remain silent about God’s works
Only pastors should declare God’s works
Avoid testifying to others about God’s help
questions.correctAnswer: I shall live and declare the works of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 17 affirms the believer’s commitment to live and actively declare God’s works, encouraging perseverance and open witness to God’s goodness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 118 highlight the role of worship and praise in family and church life?
options: The voice of rejoicing and salvation is in the tabernacles of the righteous
Praise is only for personal private moments
Worship should be avoided in gatherings
Praise is irrelevant to spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: The voice of rejoicing and salvation is in the tabernacles of the righteous
questions.explanation: Verse 15 teaches that worship and rejoicing happen within the community of the righteous, emphasizing the importance of corporate praise in family and church fellowship.

questions.question: When facing temptation or opposition, what biblical principle from Psalms 118 encourages believers to maintain their faith?
options: The right hand of the LORD doeth valiantly on behalf of the faithful
Rely on your own power alone
Avoid prayer and seek worldly solutions
questions.correctAnswer: The right hand of the LORD doeth valiantly on behalf of the faithful
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 describe the LORD’s powerful right hand acting valiantly, assuring believers that God fights for them when they remain faithful and trust in Him.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and dependence on God can be drawn from Psalms 118:19-20?
options: Ask God to open the gates of righteousness so we may enter and praise Him
Pray only when convenient and avoid persistent requests
Depend on our own merit to enter God’s presence
Ignore God’s call and live independently
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to open the gates of righteousness so we may enter and praise Him
questions.explanation: Verses 19-20 show a prayerful request to God to open the gates of righteousness, illustrating dependence on God’s mercy and grace to draw near to Him and worship.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with gratitude. According to Psalms 118, what reason is given to encourage giving thanks to the LORD?
options: Because He is good and His mercy endures forever
questions.correctAnswer: Because He is good and His mercy endures forever
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 29 emphasize that God’s goodness and enduring mercy are the foundation for continual thanksgiving, encouraging believers to cultivate gratitude regardless of circumstances.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 118, it is better to trust in princes than in the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:8-9 clearly states that it is better to trust in the LORD than to put confidence in man or princes, highlighting the superiority of trusting God over human authorities.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 118 teaches that God’s deliverance is cause for rejoicing and gladness in the day He has made.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 24 declares that the day the LORD has made is a day for rejoicing and gladness, teaching believers to celebrate God's deliverance and blessings with joy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The stone which the builders refused is become the _____ of the corner."
questions.correctAnswer: head stone
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states that the stone which the builders refused has become the head stone of the corner, symbolizing God's surprising and sovereign choice in salvation and leadership.

questions.question: How does Psalms 118 guide believers in maintaining integrity and faithfulness during persecution or opposition?
options: The LORD takes the believer's part against their enemies
Avoid faithfulness to God to prevent trouble
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD takes the believer's part against their enemies
questions.explanation: Verse 7 assures that the LORD supports those who are faithful and helps them overcome their enemies, encouraging believers to maintain integrity and trust in God's justice.

questions.question: What does Psalms 118 teach about evangelism and sharing the Gospel based on verse 26?
options: Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the LORD
Avoid sharing faith to prevent conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 26 blesses those who come in the name of the LORD, encouraging believers to actively share the Gospel and bless others as representatives of God’s kingdom.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 118 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 118.

questions.question: Which repeated phrase in Psalms 118 emphasizes God's everlasting mercy and is echoed in both the beginning and the end of the chapter?
options: The right hand of the LORD doeth valiantly
The stone which the builders refused
questions.correctAnswer: His mercy endureth for ever
questions.explanation: The phrase 'his mercy endureth for ever' appears in Psalms 118:1 and Psalms 118:29, emphasizing God's eternal mercy as a central theme of the chapter.

questions.question: In Psalms 118, the 'stone which the builders refused' is become what?
options: The head stone of the corner
questions.correctAnswer: The head stone of the corner
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:22 states that 'The stone which the builders refused is become the head stone of the corner,' a phrase often interpreted as messianic and echoed in the New Testament (e.g., Matthew 21:42).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'right hand of the LORD' in Psalms 118 according to verses 15 and 16?
options: It doeth valiantly and is exalted
It is a symbol of punishment
It is the hand that creates
It is hidden from the enemies
questions.correctAnswer: It doeth valiantly and is exalted
questions.explanation: Verses 15 and 16 highlight the LORD's right hand as mighty and exalted, symbolizing divine power and victory in ancient Near Eastern imagery.

questions.question: Which verse in Psalms 118 portrays a chiasm in the repeated mention of being surrounded by enemies and the LORD's deliverance?
questions.correctAnswer: Psalms 118:10-12
questions.explanation: Verses 10-12 repeat the theme of being surrounded by nations and enemies like bees, then declare deliverance in the name of the LORD, exhibiting chiastic parallelism.

questions.question: How does Psalms 118:14 describe the LORD in terms of salvation imagery?
options: The LORD is my strength and song, and is become my salvation
The LORD is a mighty warrior who conquers enemies
The LORD is a judge who punishes the wicked
The LORD is a shepherd who leads his flock
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is my strength and song, and is become my salvation
questions.explanation: Verse 14 uses metaphorical language, calling the LORD both 'strength' and 'song,' highlighting joy and power as aspects of salvation.

questions.question: In the context of ancient Near Eastern royal worship, what does the phrase 'Blessed be he that cometh in the name of the LORD' (Psalms 118:26) signify?
options: A royal or priestly procession entering the temple
An invocation for rain and fertility
An expression of mourning for the dead
questions.correctAnswer: A royal or priestly procession entering the temple
questions.explanation: This phrase likely refers to a celebratory procession, possibly the entrance of the king or priest, a common motif in Israelite and ancient Near Eastern worship practices.

questions.question: Which New Testament event is often connected typologically with the 'stone which the builders refused' in Psalms 118:22?
options: The rejection of Jesus as the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: The rejection of Jesus as the Messiah
questions.explanation: The stone rejected by builders is cited in Acts 4:11 and 1 Peter 2:7 as a typology for Jesus, rejected by leaders but becoming the cornerstone of faith.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 118:8 and 9 suggest that it is better to trust in human leaders than in the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:8-9 explicitly states it is better to trust in the LORD than in man or princes, emphasizing divine over human trust.

questions.question: What literary device is employed in Psalms 118 by having multiple groups (Israel, the house of Aaron, those who fear the LORD) proclaim the same message about God's mercy?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 use synonymous parallelism by having different groups declare the enduring mercy of God, reinforcing the theme through repetition.

questions.question: Which verse in Psalms 118 expresses a confident declaration of life and mission despite previous chastening?
questions.correctAnswer: Psalms 118:17
questions.explanation: Verse 17 states, 'I shall not die, but live, and declare the works of the LORD,' showing triumph over adversity.

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of 'bind the sacrifice with cords, even unto the horns of the altar' in Psalms 118:27?
options: It symbolizes dedication and completeness of the offering
It indicates a ritual binding of the priest
It shows the altar being prepared for battle
It refers to a punishment ritual
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes dedication and completeness of the offering
questions.explanation: Binding the sacrifice to the altar's horns was an ancient Near Eastern practice symbolizing the offering's complete surrender and consecration to God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 118:5 describe God's response to distress, and what might 'set me in a large place' imply in its historical context?
options: God answered and delivered the psalmist to freedom and spaciousness
God ignored the plea in distress
God sent enemies to surround the psalmist
questions.correctAnswer: God answered and delivered the psalmist to freedom and spaciousness
questions.explanation: The phrase 'set me in a large place' suggests liberation from confinement or oppression, a metaphor for divine deliverance common in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What theme is developed by the repeated use of 'the LORD is on my side' and 'I will not fear' in Psalms 118:6, and its relevance to the original audience?
options: Divine protection and courage in the face of enemies
Invitation to join a military alliance
questions.correctAnswer: Divine protection and courage in the face of enemies
questions.explanation: Verse 6 communicates confidence in God’s protection, encouraging the original Israelite audience to trust in God rather than fear human threats.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 118:24 states, 'This is the day which the LORD hath made; we will ______ and be glad in it.'
questions.correctAnswer: rejoice
questions.explanation: The verse calls for joy and gladness, underscoring gratitude for God's providence.

questions.question: How does Psalms 118:13 illustrate the interplay between divine testing and deliverance?
options: Thou hast thrust sore at me that I might fall: but the LORD helped me
The enemies have triumphed without resistance
I fell and was left without help
questions.correctAnswer: Thou hast thrust sore at me that I might fall: but the LORD helped me
questions.explanation: This verse acknowledges trials but affirms God's sustaining help, a common motif for faith under trial.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 118 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 118 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 118, what is the fundamental reason given for giving thanks to the LORD?
options: Because He is good and His mercy endures forever
Because He is mighty and powerful
Because He is a consuming fire
questions.correctAnswer: Because He is good and His mercy endures forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 118:1 and 118:29 emphasize giving thanks to the LORD because He is good and His mercy endures forever. This theme is consistent with Exodus 34:6, Lamentations 3:22, and Ephesians 2:4, which highlight God's enduring mercy and goodness.

questions.question: Who does Psalms 118 specifically call to declare that God's mercy endures forever?
options: Israel, the house of Aaron, and those who fear the LORD
The kings, the prophets, and the priests
The Gentiles, the sinners, and the outcasts
The angels, the elders, and the living creatures
questions.correctAnswer: Israel, the house of Aaron, and those who fear the LORD
questions.explanation: Verses 2-4 specifically call Israel, the house of Aaron (priests), and those who fear the LORD to proclaim God's enduring mercy, reflecting God's covenant relationship with His people as seen in Deuteronomy 7:9 and Psalm 103:17.

questions.question: What is the response of the psalmist when calling upon the LORD in distress?
options: The LORD answered and set him in a large place
The LORD sent a prophet to guide him
The LORD punished him for his sins
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD answered and set him in a large place
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that when the psalmist called upon the LORD in distress, God answered and gave him freedom and relief. This parallels Psalm 34:17-19 and Isaiah 41:10, which describe God's deliverance in times of trouble.

questions.question: According to Psalms 118, what reason does the psalmist give for not fearing man?
options: Because the LORD is on his side
Because he is hidden from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is on his side
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states that the LORD's presence on the psalmist's side removes fear of man, affirming trust in God's protection as in Isaiah 41:13, Romans 8:31, and Hebrews 13:6.

questions.question: What does the psalmist assert is better than putting confidence in princes or man?
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in the LORD
questions.explanation: Verses 8 and 9 emphasize that it is better to trust in the LORD than in man or princes, highlighting divine sovereignty over human authority, consistent with Proverbs 3:5-6 and Jeremiah 17:5-7.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe the opposition surrounding him, and what is the means of his victory?
options: Nations compassed him like bees, but he will destroy them in the name of the LORD
Enemies surrounded him like lions, but he fled to the mountains
Opponents encircled him like wolves, but he fought with his own strength
Foes surrounded him like fire, but he hid in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Nations compassed him like bees, but he will destroy them in the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verses 10-12 use the metaphor of bees to describe enemies surrounding the psalmist, but he proclaims victory by the name of the LORD. This reflects God's power to deliver as in Exodus 14:14 and 2 Chronicles 20:15.

questions.question: What does the psalmist declare about life and death in Psalms 118?
options: He shall not die but live and declare the works of the LORD
He fears death and prays for mercy
He accepts death as the final end
He believes death is inevitable and final
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not die but live and declare the works of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 17 expresses confident life and testimony enabled by God's salvation. This foreshadows resurrection themes as in John 11:25 and Romans 6:9.

questions.question: What role does the 'right hand of the LORD' play according to this psalm?
options: It is exalted and does valiantly
questions.correctAnswer: It is exalted and does valiantly
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 describe the LORD's right hand as exalted and valiant, symbolizing God's power and deliverance, consistent with Exodus 15:6 and Acts 2:33.

questions.question: How does Psalms 118 describe the stone rejected by builders, and what is its significance?
options: It became the head stone of the corner
It was hidden in the rubble
It was used as a stepping stone
questions.correctAnswer: It became the head stone of the corner
questions.explanation: Verse 22 speaks of the rejected stone becoming the cornerstone, a messianic prophecy fulfilled in Christ as affirmed in Acts 4:11 and 1 Peter 2:7.

questions.question: What does Psalms 118 describe as 'marvellous in our eyes'?
options: The LORD's doing in making the rejected stone the cornerstone
The creation of the heavens and the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD's doing in making the rejected stone the cornerstone
questions.explanation: Verse 23 declares the LORD's work in this event as marvelous, highlighting God's sovereign and redemptive plan, consistent with Isaiah 28:16 and Matthew 21:42.

questions.question: What is the attitude of the psalmist toward the day the LORD has made?
options: Rejoice and be glad in it
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoice and be glad in it
questions.explanation: Verse 24 commands rejoicing in the LORD's day, affirming God's providential control over time and history, paralleling Isaiah 61:3 and Philippians 4:4.

questions.question: What request does the psalmist make to the LORD in verse 25?
options: Grant long life to the king
questions.correctAnswer: Save now and send prosperity
questions.explanation: Verse 25 is a plea for immediate salvation and blessing, reflecting trust in God's timely intervention as in Psalm 20:6 and Nehemiah 2:20.

questions.question: Who is blessed according to Psalms 118:26?
options: He that cometh in the name of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He that cometh in the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 26 blesses those who come in the LORD's name, a phrase applied messianically to Jesus in Matthew 21:9 and Luke 13:35.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about God's chastening and its outcome?
options: The LORD hath chastened him sore but not given him over unto death
The LORD hath abandoned him to death
The LORD chastens to destroy completely
The LORD does not chasten the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD hath chastened him sore but not given him over unto death
questions.explanation: Verse 18 shows God's discipline as corrective, not destructive, aligning with Hebrews 12:6-11 and Proverbs 3:11-12 about God's loving correction.

questions.question: What is the psalmist's declaration when entering the gates of righteousness?
options: I will go in and praise the LORD
I will seek shelter and hide
questions.correctAnswer: I will go in and praise the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 19 expresses joyful entrance into God's presence with praise, consistent with Psalm 100:4 and Revelation 7:15 about worship in God's sanctuary.
